## Jenkins run failure total incident
This incident type refers to a situation where there has been a total failure in running Jenkins jobs. Jenkins is a popular automation server used for building, testing, and deploying applications. When such an incident occurs, it can lead to significant downtime and issues in the software development and delivery process. The incident may be triggered by factors such as misconfiguration, code errors, or infrastructure issues. Resolving the issue promptly is critical to minimize the impact on the software development process.

cells.name: cell_2
cells.content: ## 1. Check the status of the Jenkins service

cells.name: cell_3
cells.content: (host | host_name=$HOST_NAME) union (pod | k8s_cluster_name=$K8S_CLUSTER_NAME | namespace=$NAMESPACE) | `systemctl status jenkins`

cells.name: cell_4
cells.content: ## 2. Check the logs for any errors or warnings

cells.name: cell_5
cells.content: (host | host_name=$HOST_NAME) union (pod | k8s_cluster_name=$K8S_CLUSTER_NAME | namespace=$NAMESPACE) | `journalctl -u jenkins --no-pager --since "2 hours ago"`

cells.name: cell_7
cells.content: (host | host_name=$HOST_NAME) union (pod | k8s_cluster_name=$K8S_CLUSTER_NAME | namespace=$NAMESPACE) | `sudo su - jenkins -c "java -jar /usr/share/jenkins/jenkins.war --check"`

cells.name: cell_8
cells.content: ## 4. Check the connectivity to the Jenkins instance

cells.content: ## 5. Check the Jenkins job configuration for any errors

cells.content: ## 6. Check the Jenkins build history for any failed builds

cells.content: ## Infrastructure issues: When running Jenkins on an infrastructure that is not properly set up, there may be issues with resources such as memory, disk space, or network connectivity. This could result in failed jobs and ultimately a total failure of the system.
